text: Dutch is literally one of the prettiest languages ever created with perfect words and sounds, and most speakers of Dutch use soft Gs and medium Gs, only in Amsterdam the harder Gs are used a lot, and Swedish is totally not prettier than Norwegian, Swedish is one of the least prettier Nordic languages, though it is still pretty, while Norwegian Bokm√•l has the best spelling / aspect, definitely better looking than both Swedish and Danish spelling, and, Icelandic is definitely the most feminine (but also the most masculine) language ever, just like Norse and English and Dutch, these four languages all sound the most feminine when spoken by speakers with higher voices that are naturally pretty and light, and they also sound the most alpha and the most masculine when spoken by speakers with deeper voices, having the coolest and the most modern pronunciation rules, and Danish also, and the pronunciation rules are definitely better in Danish than in Norwegian and Swedish, but they are easier in Norwegian, so Norwegian and Icelandic and Norse are great options to start with, and I highly recommend learning all at the same time! I am already advanced level in Norwegian and very close to advanced level in Icelandic (upper intermediate level, and also in Norse and German) and upper advanced level in Dutch, which is definitely the easiest language or one of the easiest languages to learn for English speakers, and I highly recommend using the soft G and the soft normal R + the Americanized R aka de gooise R which have the best and most refined sound, and, I am learning 15+ languages at the moment and mostly prioritizing Icelandic and Norse and Welsh over the past few weeks! Around 4:23 is vey incorrect, not a Latin language, and it‚Äôs one of the most non-pretty languages ever, so it doesn‚Äôt even belong on the same list with perfect and amazing languages such as the Germanic languages and the modern Celtic languages and the Latin languages and Slovene and Hungarian (these ones are the real pretty languages) and also Finnish / Latvian / Estonian, which also have mostly pretty words and nice word endings! Also, the harsh Hs in Arabic are way harsher than the hard Gs used in Dutch, and unlike Dutch, which has all sorts of Gs from the softest to the hardest G, Arabic has no soft H versions, and Arabic isn‚Äôt a pretty language as it only has a few pretty words, maybe ten to twenty percent of the words, while most words are just neutral, so it‚Äôs an avrg language, same as Polish and Russian and Bulgarian etc! Slovene is definitely the prettiest and most refined Slavic language, Hungarian is a pretty language that‚Äôs a way better option than Turkish (as it has the good sounds and the good letter combinations and the good pretty word endings found in Turkish, minus the non-pretty ones, plus Hungarian has a way lighter spelling and a very organized aspect, having been influenced a lot by Germanic languages, so if one is thinking about learning Turkish, one should definitely learn Hungarian instead of Turkish) and, the prettiest Latin languages are Galician / Brazilian Portuguese / Gallo and Occitan and Latin are also real pretty and are even prettier than Spanish and Italian and French etc!
author: @FrozenMermaid666

text:
Around 4:23 is very incorrect, it‚Äôs not a Latin language at all, not even true Slavic, and it is one of the most non-pretty and uncouth looking / sounding languages ever with embarrassingly funny sounding words and word endings, totally not an Alpha language, it‚Äôs as non-pretty as Indian languages and Japanese and African languages lol, and, the most accurate classification would be Thracian-Aslavic or something similar, technically those groups of languages were made by greek dudes and dudes that moved away from Greece, so it has a lot more similarities with Greek and languages such as Bulgarian and Serbian and Albanian ‚Äî while Germanic languages are all amazing languages, with Icelandic / Norse / English / Dutch / Norwegian / Danish being the best ever! 

Re the language Farsi or Persian etc, it is actually an Arabic language, not an European language, as it looks and sounds Arabic! In truth, all languages come from Proto European, in one way or another, anyway, so it isn‚Äôt a complete or really accurate classification, plus European languages are not similar to Indian languages at all, and Indian languages are similar to Arabic languages, as they have influenced each other! Thing is, many of the less known languages have been misclassified as they haven‚Äôt been properly analyzed and compared to the languages spoken in the neighboring countries, so not all the classifications are accurate or complete!¬†

As for Hungarian, it is one of the pretty languages, unlike most languages on this list, and most of the ‚Äòcases‚Äô are actually just the postpositions aka the prepositions of the agglutinative languages, which are added to the noun and written as one word, and Hungarian is a category 2 language, so it‚Äôs very easy to read / learn / memorize etc and it has a category 1 pronunciation, and it has mostly pretty words like Germanic languages and modern Celtic languages!

text:
Wow, ¬†@FrozenMermaid666¬†, what a burst of flow... I love it but it's difficult to follow, need to borrow a full stop? Do you happen to be Dutch, I wonder? I speak Dutch and several other European languages and Dutch is by far the easiest to learn (if you're motivated enough, which is seldom the case). It's basically simplified German with a heavy pronunciation twist and some ingredients of Frisian language, which in turn is closer to English. But easy languages are not a great tool for expression. The ultimate tool for evaluating a language apart from your personal preferences ("the melody") is the literature. The great achievements in writing and poetry define the superiority of a language. So next to funny Simp's rankings, thumbs up to those, the objective ranking would still put Russian, German, French, Spanish, (sorry Italians and English!) in the first tier, and then Polish, Serbian, Bulgarian, Czech, Irish, Armenian and then only Scandinavian languages. Hungary has great culture but the language barrier is too high for me to absorb their superb poetry (in music they are second to none). Practically all the pillars of the Christianity rest on the heritage of Greek language solely, so that cannot be taken out of equation too. The huge problem is that the languages promptly reflect the shifts in cultural and spiritual development, so most of the recent "great" languages from the objective first tier and all those that I speak succumb to decay we are witnessing in this century, and especially that of the last several years. 
P. S. If you are going to learn Portuguese, go definitely instead learn Serbian, it sounds similarly macho and is better organized, has some borrowed German and Turkish words for your convenience plus covers four or five more lands in the region.

text: Urdu is written in the Persian Script, not the Arabic Script. Persian has additional sounds and letters, that is, Arabic letters are a subset of Persian, (Farsi) more or less. Hindi and Urdu are very similar, but have different alphabets, and a good deal of different vocabulary. It is possible to go from one to the other with relative ease. Between the two, it is commonly said that there is about 30 percent vocabulary in one and exclusive of the other. In useful vocabulary, I'd guess it is closer to 20 percent. The differences are very regional, with the prevalence of Urdu gaining with the closeness of the Mogul court in northern Pakistan, later in Afghanistan.  Everyone who speaks any of these languages is extremely touchy for some reason.

text:
Oh, c'mon, Hindi does belong in the Gigachad layer!

You would unlock a lot of DLC (probably one of the highest in the world).

And I can promise you that if a foreigner speaks in Hindi (but with a foreign accent, which is important), the locals would go crazy and make that foreigner the next Bollywood star (earning billions if not trillions of rupees!).

The script is pretty cool because it's very easy to read. It's not like English or French, where multiple words spelled in the same way can have different pronunciations. You read it in exactly the way it is written (kind of similar to the way Spanish is). 

And if you learn the script, you will also have access to tonnes of cryptic DLC (read: Ancient scriptures written in Sanskrit, which is a different language written in a pretty similar script, but still gets you closer to it) where you just might unlock the meaning of life and the universe.

Also, you get closer to comprehension of some of the other Indian languages (Gujarati, Marathi, Bangla, etc.), which can make learning them a bit easier.

What's not to like?

text: 18:00 everybody's wrong about Bulgarian being easy! even after speaking B2 Russian, Bulgarian is quite difficult! firstly Grammar is quite difficult and different from other Slavic languages, speaking Russian means you can already understand high register vocabulary such as about politics, administration and science, but not being able to understand a lot of everyday speech... the tenses... etc.. plus note that it does have three Grammatical cases, accusative, vocative and nominative
author: @kobikaicalev175

text: 13:00 don't believe the hype, Hungarian so called grammatical cases are not cases, only suffixes, and are just like prepositions (ie. postpositions), there are even articles about it, but it's just obvious and that's from a learners perspective as well, I did some Hungarian after a lot of Finnish, and Finnish's cases are really cases. the thing with Hungarian is that the postpositions do not mark each item in the syntax tree branch, as is the cases, with cases. also note, even for Finnish, the case system is much easier than Slavic, since there's no grammatical gender, and because Nouns and Adjectives are marked with the same endings in Finno-Ugric. so from a learners perspective, every Slavic case - should be multiplied by 6 (gender, noun vs adjektiv). I've learnt about B2 Russian, B1 Polish and Bulgarian, for my milage
author: @kobikaicalev175

text:
Im a Finnish and i have been learning arabic for a year now. Every time i'm frustrated with learning arabic, im glad im not learning finnish :D 15 cases is nuts. Few eamples below.
base word = Koira = a dog
Koirassani = in my dog
Koirastasi = from your dog
Koiraasi = of your dog 
Koiraani = of my dog
Etc 11 other officials, these are singular. then are the "unofficials" (not taught in school but is understantable and follows grammatical rules)
Koirastasikohan = i wonder if of from your dog
Koirassammekohan = i wonder if there is in our dog
Koirallemmeko = to our dog?
Koiraltasiko = form your dog?
Koirastasiko = of your dog?
Koirinemme = with our dog

Example: "koirastasikohan nuo punkit tippuivat?" = I wonder if those tics fell off from your dog. "L√§hdemme koirinemme heti"= we leave with our dogs now!

Im not saying its the hardest language, but its a hard language to learn even for a finn, thats why i have enormous respect for anyone willing to even think about learning this bad joke called finnish language, because i know i wouldn't if this wouldn't be my native language. Its a cool as a secret language though.

text:
I'm wondering if German has a bad reputation for sounding aggressive because people watched footage of Hitler's. But that's not how Germans normally speak. Just like how you pronounced "anyung ha seyo" is not how Koreans say it. It's said a lot smoother than how you said it. You kind of over acted out your misinformed top down impression of Korean in how your pronounced anyung ha seyo was said in a little too strong of an accent to stress your point. I'm sure it's meant to illustrate what you're trying to communicate. 
You've got too much of a linguistic background to say that you're for misinformed, but I did want to point out some inaccuracies.
author: @DavidLeeKim

text:
Your comment on Hangul (Korean script) was a little uninformed. You have a strong linguistic background so you do approach each language with having had researched the language for sure. 
You're saying that the "circles can get old after seeing them too often". I'm sure that can be true for a lot of language learners in their subjective experience with learning Korean. You have to talk about how Korean script is one THE BEST written language on Earth because it's designed after how the mouth is shaped when pronouncing these words. So those circles represent what shape your mouth is in. I recommend you add more linguistic research if you speak further on it. I'd imagine you're able to do that. A little from Google on Hangul. 
"Google search of What are the best written languages?"
"The writing system used in Korean, this system is considered one of the best in the world.¬†It's a combination of an alphabet and syllabary, with symbols that reflect the sounds in words and are organized into syllabic blocks.¬†King Sejong the Great is credited with designing Hangul in the 15th century." King Sejong is related to me. His older brother, my ancestor, gave up the throne and passed it on to him.

text:
23:39 Farsi or Persian as people like foreigners to call their language that way. Is not only spoken in Iran it is the official language of Afghanistan and Tajikistan, but they are referred to with different names  Dari and Tajik. But they are much more intelligable than the dialects of Arabic which can't even understand each other. Persian speakers communicate with each other without any problem. There are many videos online discussing their differences. Btw it is spoken by around 40% of people in Uzbekistan.  So overall, it has 130M speakers that if you learn one dialect, you'll understand the others without any problems. So, I would give it a much higher rank. I'm really surprised that u put it below pashto.

As for ur traveling concerns there tons of travelers vlog from Americans visiting Iran on YouTube so check them out and you'll see how it is different from your imagination.

text:
It's important to mention too that the best languages to learn also depends on where you live.
Be sure to learn the most common languages in your country. Not everyone will be bothered to speak the language of your country, and it's important to still be able to communicate with them.
Also, these sorts of videos are extremely subjective. I know I'd rank these languages very differently because there are points and even hypocrisy and bias I disagree with. It's better to look at objective data such as countries these languages are spoken in and how many people speak them in your country.

text: You can't say Greek is average... and call yourself a language learner! First of all, learning Greek to a C level or better, gives you a significant foundation for all European languages, including Latin. It gives you not only context on how grammar evolved, how etymologies came to be, but also an understanding of advanced words in countless other languages... Of the top of my head, "schema" moved from Greek to Latin to Dutch to Indonesian, in this progression, also Parthian, Russian, Turkish, and Albanian among many others. It's the closest you can get to a functional earlier Indo-European language that you can still speak today. Secondly, you say Arabic is important to learn for the Quran, and it is indeed. But you overlook that the New Testament - including the Gospel itself! - is in Koine Greek... The one book you should strive to study! The philosophical and theological texts the West in general is based on are 99% in Greek. I have no clue where you're from, but you're out of touch with Europe and our culture, probably also with God.

text: Advice for trying to learn Japanese and ignoring western weeb culture, which is unfortunately very much a thing, just focus purely on the language. Pursue it academically out of interest and that it is a really fascinating language. It is that simple. Once you get to around N3 (or even N4) I would say you're typically out of the "weeb level" of the language. Most people who are of that calibre tend to drop out once they realise their love of anime does not translate to the determination required for even attaining basic proficiency with a language so different from western ones.

text:
I was enjoying watching this until you got to Japanese and put it in dogwater because of a small toxic community of weeaboos, thought you would look at it as only a language and what it‚Äôs like interacting with native speakers in the language ..just like you did for a lot of other languages up to that point. 
Wish you looked at it more for aesthetics and history rather than a toxic net culture. I‚Äôve done tea üçµ ceremony and lived in Japan and there‚Äôs a lot more depth to it than anime or weebs. 
But I agree that too many people nowadays only study it because of anime and sometimes Japanese people just assume I love anime. But I‚Äôve been fluent for 20 years and learned a plethora of ways, anime is just one side-quest or supplementary source. 
But it‚Äôs also a part of some modern culture and seiyuu (voice actors) really have to go through a ton of training and are not just voice actors but celebrities and could be singers/or just very well known personalities throughout Japan as well. 
Like Yuuki Aoi at 3 years old started out as a child actress before she was a seiyuu and many voice actors have been in hundreds or thousands of anime/films/games/productions. It‚Äôs really intense how much the entertainment industry cranks out from Japan. It‚Äôs really great for hardcore gamers or people that might like Nintendo too. Not just anime, there‚Äôs games too üòÇlol jk

text:
The problem with Russian aren't really rules or grammar. It's that the grammar is extremely fluid and the proper word order is optional, but also most changes in the grammar are deliberate and actually mean something. Something you are unlikely to ever learn from a text book.
It can be moderately easy to talk like a dictionary, but that's not how people actually talk.
It's like yoda-speak has a meaning and a vibe in English, except in Russian there are countless yoda-speaks, and each has its own vibes and meanings, and they are switched around constantly. Because the words have declinations, most word orders will convey the basic meaning just fine regardless how jumbled the words are, and this is actually used all the time to add additional layer of meaning on top.
This is something that is most naturally learned by actually talking to people in different contexts to absorb their way of speaking

If you want to learn Russian to read Russian literature, that's something to keep in mind, because if you aren't living in Russia it can take you a long time to know it good enough to really upgrade your comprehension of literature from what you were getting with translations. Oh, and btw those vibes were different historically. So, say, learning modern vibes will not really allow you to appreciate Bukgakov. You'd have to read a lot of Soviet literature and watch Soviet movies first. It very well may be that it in the end it may mot be worth it

author: @danielsmokesmids

text:
¬†@danielsmokesmids¬† well, maybe I was too harsh :) it depends on the goal. If you like the learning itself, it's certainly a great language for that. You can progress and progress and progress and always have something new, some new horizons. But if you want minimal effort for maximum benefit, maximum expansion of available media as quickly as possible, that's probably not the best candidate. I'd probably pick Spanish for that or something

There are Russian writers that are more verbose like Tolstoy and they are more suitable for intermediate learners, but then again their translations are also decent. Bulgakov in particular translates horribly and English version of Master and Margarita is an atrocity compared to the smart light hearted brevity of the original where just a few words can create entire characters. But learning Russian up to a level to be able to fluently get that will probably take an unreasonable amount of time

It's easier in the movies since intonation and emphasis make the intent obvious
author: @NJ-wb1cz

text:
As a russian native I'm curious of what you're saying. First I was gonna disagree but you seem well articulate and thorough person. Can you give me some examples of changes in the fluid grammar, yoda-speaks and the other quirks you mentioned?
I also have a feeling that you got overcharmed by diversity of people's ways to speak which can be just a representation of illiterate language skills of natives. There's a such small group of people who can actually articulate their thoughts in a bookish manner. Dont worry, it doesn't sound old-fashioned, they just immediately get considered as superiors in any circle (maybe except teenagers under 15 and provincial criminals under 30). And  I would say its even the easiest way to get famous in Russia - just be bookishly eloquent - and everyone simply wanna listen to you more.
author: @rueentur

text:
And I'm surprised you find Bulgakov's language way different. I could agree if you'd say it about Dostoyevski or Chekhov, they're really nuts even for natives. But for me Bulgakov is a benchmark of actual russian. Same is about soviet period literature and movies. For me its literally modern russian excluding slang. And dont get me wrong, I'm zoomer.
Btw if you interested to acquire beautiful russian I can suggest you my subjective list of writers. It's gonna be Bulgakov, Dovlatov, Gogol, early Akunin, Lermontov, Limonov. Maybe you can try –ê–Ω–¥—Ä–µ–π –ë–µ–ª—ã–π and his "–ü–µ—Ç–µ—Ä–±—É—Ä–≥". No need Nabokov, he's too much

text: Tagalog usually puts english words on a sentence because of two things: the word will be difficult to say or its cringey as hell, some words are way too formal to be even used in a casual conversation. These words can also be rooted on spanish or old tagalog and not to mention the vast dialects that we have. It just makes thing easier for us, It might be bad in terms of cultural preservation to us but it is quite beneficial to us. Philippines is among one of the countries where speaking english is common and the accent is not too far from American natives compared to other asian countries.

text:
You're so off on afrikaans my bru.

1. Dutch is messed up Afrikaans
2. The majority of people who speak Afrikaans aren't the Afrikaners but a group called "Coloured" which is a separate specific name for an ethnic group of mixed people in South Africa 
3. The grammar is super interesting bc it's at least partially a creole language, it's gotten rid of things like person conjugation and the irregular past tense in favor of a completely regular new past tense based on the perfect, but in its place you get cool creole constructions like reduplication (repeating a word twice to mean something different) and special "intensiewe vorme" for adjectives (ex. bang=scared, but doodbang (deadscared) = very scared, hoog=tall/high but hemelhoog (heavenhigh)= super tall/high etc.) which add back in a certain degree of fun new stuff for an English speaker 
4. The first writing in Afrikaans was done in Arabic script and I'm pretty sure still is written in that script occasionally by the Cape Muslim community, whose Afrikaans also happens to have a ton of Malay and other language influences in it 
5. Because the Dutch speak a sort of broken Afrikaans, you unlock a lot of their DLC just by learning it and you'll always have a fun party trick to bust out around the Hollanders/kaaskoppe bc they think it's very funny when you speak the proper, based form of their language around them 
6. Afrikaans speakers, both afrikaners and Coloured, do turn backflips if they find out you're learning their language 
7. You can probably learn it faster than just about any other language if you natively speak English, and the languages are so closely related that you can write sentences that make sense in both (ex. "my pen is in my hand" is a perfectly valid sentence in afrikaans) but esp if you learn a variety like Kaaps you'll still have a ton of cool words from South African languages and even languages of Asia

in conclusion: leer afrikaans jou doos dis 'n pragtige taal

¬†@Emerald_City_¬† I sure do, but at some point you gotta have some merit in what you say.
Like where's the limit of comedy and misinformed when considering what his channel is about?!
Basically i can definitely stand clich√©s jokes or similar, yet when the whole point becomes trying to sound outrageous for the sake of views i call that out.
I'll prove my point:
Is the video about tips for others on what language might be useful to learn as of today?
Is it instead based only on his own convenience since he says HE knows french and spanish thus doesn't need italian?
Is it a comedy skit that disregards facts and uses exaggerations for laugh effect?
There you go, looks to me as another drop in the sea of clickbaity and over the top youtubers that provide much arms flailing and little content. Shame, could have been better considering the vast audience he has.

text: not so easy to imagine, what would be the real reasons to learn ukrainian in 2024. from the linguistics view, ukrainian, besides the belarusian, is closest to russian and have about 60-70% words in common. the grammar is also differ rather barely. if you know russian, it's enough to listen ukrainian tv a week or two to understand almost all common ukrainian, except some specific or dialect words, most of which, however, understandable in context. on the other side, speakin ukrainian clearly is harder for those who speaks russian - as the pronounciation is tightly similar in both, but differ in so small details (chiefly word stressses and alternations like i-o, i-—ã, –∞-—è), that russian speakers just don't account that, but (some of) ukrainians catch such the errors and mispronounciations (painfully and sometimes eagerly in these hard times).

text:
I can't believe Welsh was left out.  It is the most beautiful sounding language, and listening to poetry in Welsh will literally cause an orgasm in your brain.

It's so beautiful that even elves from Middle Earth invaded earth and stole parts of it to make their own conlan (Sindarin).  When even elves crave the sounds of your language, you know it is gigachad.

King Aurthur (who was absolutely 100% a real king of the British Isles) spoke it, and the best tales of him were all written in Welsh, since it was the only language noble enough to fully capture his legend.

Speaking of kings of the British Isles, the current king of England took time to learn Welsh, and if he picked it as a critical language to learn in today's world, then you can be sure you won't be wasting your time!

Welsh better be included for his list in 2025, or else I'm quitting this channel, and moving to North Korea.

text:
A little history on the topic of Ukrainian and Russian languages:
Ukrainian (and Belarusian) came from the Ruthenian language, which was a spoken language in the Middle Ages. Russian came from the Church Slavonic, written language, which, in turn, was invented by Cyril and Methodius on the basis of Proto-Bulgarian, most likely to unite peoples who did not know Slavic languages. So basically Ruthenian and Church Slavonic languages were like Spanish/Italian/etc and Latin.

text:
Dude, no. Cyril and Methodius just invented Cyrillic alphabet, not the language.

A quote from Wikipedia for you:
"Old East Slavic (traditionally also Old Russian) was a language (or a group of dialects) used by the East Slavs from the 7th or 8th century to the 13th or 14th century, until it diverged into the Russian and Ruthenian languages. Ruthenian eventually evolved into the Belarusian, Rusyn, and Ukrainian languages".

In Russian the names of the languages are: Old East Slavic - –î—Ä–µ–≤–Ω–µ—Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π,  Ruthenian - –ó–∞–ø–∞–¥–Ω–æ—Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π (Ukrainians and Belarusians might also call it –°—Ç–∞—Ä–æ—É–∫—Ä–∞–∏–Ω—Å–∫–∏–π –∏ –°—Ç–∞—Ä–æ–±–µ–ª–æ—Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π), Russian of that time - –°—Ç–∞—Ä–æ—Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–∏–π.
All of 4 modern East Slavic languages were influenced by Old Church Slavonic (which was indeed a South Slavic language), but Russian was influenced by it a bit more. And due to Union of Lublin, Ukrainian, Rusyn and Belarusian were influenced by Polish (Russian was influenced by Polish too, but to a lesser extent).
author: @Langermar

text:
¬†@Langermar¬† You are wrong. They did invent/create the language itself. A translated quote from Wikipedia for you: "Cyril and Methodius are saints of the Orthodox and Catholic churches, missionary brothers from the city of Thessaloniki, creators of the Old Church Slavonic alphabet and the Church Slavonic language ."
Another one from the language page itself: "An early form of Church Slavonic goes back to the Solunsky dialect of the Old (Proto) Bulgarian language, native to the creators of the written Old Church Slavonic language, Cyril and Methodius "

Now, why is it written on Wikipedia that Old East Slavic diverged into Russian if Russian is based on Old Church Slavonic (aka Proto Bulgarian) that has nothing to deal with Old East Slavic? As Church Slavonic influenced Ruthenian in some ways, Old East Slavic and Ruthenian influenced Old Church Slavonic. Languages do not suddenly appear and disappear, afterall. They are constantly evolving, drawing on some elements from neighboring languages. Most likely this is what was meant.
To better understand what Russian language is, let's take a look at the work of B.A. Uspensky ‚ÄúA brief outline of the history of the Russian literary language‚Äù 1994, or, more specifically, at his conclusions: 
‚ÄúThe Russian language is not, in principle, opposed to Church Slavonic, but is united with it at a deep level: ¬´Church Slavonic¬ª and ¬´Russian¬ª are essentially the same language, and the Russian spoken language appears as a result of the deterioration of the ¬´Church Slavonic¬ª language, caused mainly by foreign language influence."

Russian came from the Church Slavonic, pretty much an artificial Slavic language, not Old East Slavic. But why would the Slavs base their language on an artificial Slavic language if they have their own Slavic language? Well, it's because on the territory of modern Russia they did not speak Slavic languages back then. It was not the Slavs who lived here, but mostly the Finno-Ugrians. Except for Novgorod, which was captured only in the 15th century, of course. This can be understood from the burial mound excavations of Uvarov, from anthropological data and the results of Alekseeva‚Äôs analysis, research by the Balanovskys, and others. In the same work by Uspensky it is written that non-Slavic tribes used Church Slavonic in their external relations as a ‚Äúlingua franca‚Äù. In other words, Church Slavonic was uniting people who did not know Slavic languages.

Hope that clears things out. In the end, I want to say that not everything is written in Wikipedia, especially when a topic is a completely foreighn language and history (in our case, English Wikipedia on Ukranian and Russian history and language). You have to dig deeper, read science works of historians of those regions to which the topic concerns. Which, of course, is not always possible due to the language barrier.

text:
¬†@Emerald_City_¬† I took information not from Wikipedia, but from the works of modern historians (mostly USSR and Russian ones, btw), as well as looking through ancient documents. I can name all of them if you want.

You need to know how to read Wikipedia correctly, look at what sources it relies on, and what kind of sources they are, and by whom they were written. The problem is that Wikipedia often does not take into account all available sources, as well as the fact that it may contain manipulation or not reliable information (for example, something that breaks the trend, isolated cases). This is a problem of both Russian and Ukrainian Wikipedia.

author: @askalite

text: Hindi and Urdu are mutually intelligible in the colloquial register. If you are a native/advanced speaker, you can notice a few differences. Urdu speakers will use a lot more Arabic and Persian derived words while Hindi speakers will use more Sanskrit derived words. When it comes to accent, one thing that I have noticed is that Hindi speakers pronounce 'z' or 'ÿ≤' as 'j'. For example, when saying 'Cumin', Urdu speakers say 'Zeera' while Hindi speakers say 'Jeera'. I believe the accent differences come from the different scripts that they use. Certain sounds are found in the Arabic or Nastaliq script that are not found in the Sanskrit or Devanagari script and vice versa. Of course, there might be other factors contributing to the accent differences that I don't know of.

text:
As a student of Bulgarian, and a husband to an Ethnic Bulgarian, and a frequent enough visitor to Bulgaria üáßüá¨ ‚Ä¶ you sir are COMPLETELY wrong about Bulgarian languages ‚Äúcases‚Äù‚Ä¶ clearly you never studied the language. 

There are MORE verb cases than English, all nouns and adjectives decline. There are 2 forms for pronouns long and short and they are BRUTAL to learn how to properly place in a sentence because the order is completely different than English.   

There is something called ‚ÄúVerb Aspect‚Äù  that is designed to keep anyone born outside of Bulgaria from ever understanding that rule‚Ä¶ lol

To Bulgarian‚Äôs credit, it is a strictly phonetic language so, unlike Russian, you don‚Äôt have to change vowel pronunciation based on location in a word.  You pronounce it as it‚Äôs written.   


Bulgarian will allow you to study Slavonic if you are going to be singing or chanting in Eastern orthodox religious services 

It‚Äôs an incredible language just also saturated with Latin and Greek because of its geographical proximity within the old Roman Empire

text: As a Hungarian, who is bilingual, and studies to be an EFL and baguette language teacher, I would really encourage you to try learning a finno-ugric language. Yes, there is a lot of grammar and a bunch of irregularities , but I think it would be fun to learn one from scratch as a beginner. They are also backflip languages, at least in Hungary, if a foreigner speaks decent basic Hungarian, everyone will do 53729 backflips for you, without touching the ground and feed you p√∂rk√∂lt, t√∫r√≥rudi and p√°linka for the rest of your life. (Just kidding, but foreigners who try to learn it are usually really appreciated, since it's quite challenging ). I am currently B2 at Spanish and A2 in Dutch, but  I want to learn a bunch of other ones, including all official languages of the EU (after Spanish and Dutch I'll probably start with Estonian or Finnish, because I think it would be super fun to learn both of them due to the linguistic relationship with Hungarian, and they sound super nice) plus  anime language and Basque. Also, Finnish should be put into the gigachad their, just like other uralic languages, it inspired Tolkien to create Elvish.

text: Someone should tell Language Simp that Ukrainian, while not "dead" as Latin, but rather "unborn" language itself. Ignorant foreigners may think that everyone in Ukraine speaks it, but that couldn't be farther from the truth. Ukrainian is mainly used for political reasons on official level. Ordinary people in Ukraine, at least most of them, speak Russian (or other language depending on the region). That also means that there's no movies or books in Ukrainian. Well, there are some but it's barely enough to justify wasting time on learning it. Thus, putting Ukrainian, which is an absolute waste of time to learn, in gigachad level is kinda hypocrite considering that you had some more worthy languages lower, but i guess it was more a political decision too. Anyway, if you wanna learn the language that no one speaks, you'd be a lot better off devoting yourself to Latin, it still has some uses even today.

text:
There is no objectively hard or easy language to learn, as it highly depends on which languages you already know for the most part :D
Turkish is my mother language, I use it very little though and I know both German as well as English 1000 times better than Turkish xD (living in Germany)
author: @miraculix743

text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã¬†@miraculix743¬†turkish isn't difficult to learn.
It took me about 2 years to become fluent. And even tho i partially agree that the difficulty of learning a language can depend on what your native language is, but it doesn't mean that a language can't be objectively hard or easy. Arabic and Chinese are the hardest languages in the world, and arabic specifically is very challenging, however turkish even tho i like it, it is not that hard of a language to learn once u figure out how it works. I also speak Arabic English, French, and Turkish. :)
author: @zivan6179

text:
¬†@zivan6179¬† Difficulty of language is relative to which languages you already know for a big part, and your age.
A baby soaks up any language around it, no matter how easy or hard it may seem for older people for example

Turkish is easier for someone who grew up with languages which use the same letters. However, Korean, Russian, Chinese, and more languages with extremely different alphabets and symbols, diverse grammar and grammatical rules are harder to learn in a sense.
What I mean though is that it is still very subjective - someone who only knows English and is EXTREMELY interested in learning Chinese for example, and has the talent and hard work to go with it, will learn it easier than a language which is generally considered easier which does not pique their interest though

text: ¬†@maca_atomica_animacoes¬† I apologize, you are right, it seems that I've mistaken, what I meant is that Italian, French, Spanish and Portuguese derive from the same root on the romance language family tree while these are derived from Italo-Western which later became Proto-Italian (now Italian) Ibero-romance (now Spanish and Portuguese)and Gallo-Romance(now French), Romanian comes from Easter-Romance which became Balkan-Romance (now Romanian). Thanks a lot for correcting my big mistake!
author: @dariuslisandru-pp6lp

text: ¬†@dariuslisandru-pp6lp¬† Actually, Romanian is the closest language to Latin! You have no idea what you are talking about.
author: @danascully6698

text:
¬†@danascully6698¬† That is a frequent urban myth, that Romanian is the closest living language to Latin. 

However, these claims cannot be further from the truth, since the only criteria where Romanian would qualify is in terms of grammar. In other aspects such as phonology, vocabulary, discourse, and intonation, Italian trounces Romanian in being the closest to Latin, since Romanian is heavily influenced by Slavic languages.

According to linguist Mario Pei, he used all of these criteria to determine the closest living language to Latin, and came up with this scorecard (lower percentages indicate less deviation from Latin):
Sardinian - 8%
Italian - 12%
Spanish - 20%
Romanian - 23.5%
Occitan - 25%
Portuguese - 31%
French - 44%
Out of the major Romance languages, Italian is the closest to Latin and has about half the deviation from Latin that Romanian does. The closest to Latin overall is Sardinian. So try researching more then 2 min next time before accusing me, ok have a great day.
author: @dariuslisandru-pp6lp

text: ¬†@dariuslisandru-pp6lp¬† You contradict yourself. The first time you say that Romanian is the most distant from Latin, but with the data you display, you prove that you spoke nonsense. The Romanian language is at least half as close linguistically to Latin as compared to the other Neo-Latin languages, and grammatically it is the closest to Latin. Second, how could Romanian be massively influenced by Slavonic when the percentage of words apparently of Slavic origin is only 10-11%? Established by linguists, not by you or me! I say words apparently of Slavic origin because they could just as likely be of Thracian-Dacian or Indo-European origin and be taken over by much younger Slavic languages from the ancient Romanian language and not the other way around! I don't want to offend you, but stop making unrealistic and unfounded statements, just because that's how you think things should be. Believe me, I'm much more authorized in the field, I know much more than you and I don't make statements as I would like them to be, but according to the existing reality and established by data and statistics that don't lie.

text:
This mindless globalization when words are taken from another language family and "you shut up and speak them as it's already is a norm here" is bogus.
As a native Russian Federation speaker I had and still have a hard time understanding the roots of a given word with implications of its deeper meaning and interconnectedness with other words.

a. It's like there's a word "—Å–º–µ—Ä—Ç—å" in Russian that directly translates as "death", yet there's something a bit more profound is going on.
b.When you put in a letter you can get "—Å–º–µ—Ä–∏—Ç—å" which now means "take a measurement".
c. Exchange a letter and it becomes "—Å–º–∏—Ä–∏—Ç—å" or "to suppress".
d.1. Though one contemplating the word "—Å–º–∏—Ä–∏—Ç—å" can place shift emphasis from widespread "—Å–º–∏—Ä–∏ÃÅ—Ç—å" to  "—Å–º–∏ÃÅ—Ä–∏—Ç—å" (notice the accent mark).
d.2 "–°–º–∏ÃÅ—Ä–∏—Ç—å" is not a generally accepted pronunciation, though for a good enough speaker and listener its pertains to something like "to make somebody become one with the world" and "to make peace with somebody".
d.3 Yeah, "–º–∏—Ä" by itself is about both "peace" and "world".
e. One can even make a jump to "—Å–º–∏—Ä–µ–Ω–∏–µ" which is "humility".  

–°–º–µ—Ä—Ç—å - —Å–º–µ—Ä–∏—Ç—å - —Å–º–∏—Ä–∏ÃÅ—Ç—å - —Å–º–∏ÃÅ—Ä–∏—Ç—å - —Å–º–∏—Ä–µ–Ω–∏–µ.
Death - measure - suppress - make peace with somebody or become one with the world - humility.

And yeah, we are allowed to that tricks since russische Sprache geared towards being more of a synthetic Sprache where you bend word structure more than sentence structure to produce intended results.

One can't do the same thing with for example "–ø–∞—Ä–∞—à—É—Ç" or "parachute" and "–∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä" or "computer".
To seek and play around with the meanings of those words: "–ø–∞—Ä–∞—à—É—Ç" taken directly from French "parachute" and "–∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä" imported from British "computer" - you are to go to the source languages.
 
This figuring out another language to figure out your own is more pronounced in the realm of science. Basically, math, computer science, biology, economics sounds like a foreign language in disguise as many terms are literally foreign terms and that creates a sublime language barrier for Russians to study any given science.

Russian sure is Indo-European language like French and English and Greek and what not, but Slavic group seems really distinct from Romanic, Germanic and Hellenic and what not.

Even though the government's discourse is about maintaining the purity of the language, rejecting "Western" influence, English words pop up in a daily live in Russian now more prominently than a decade ago and there's no care with which new words are imported and it feels like Russian is left to its own devices, like neither care nor consideration is given for its future.

When I want to speak a language, I don't want to speak another American, no disrespect for British intended.

---
So, people brave and free on time enough to read up to this point, can you, please, reply by pointing out languages that stay true to their uniqueness even among the onslaught of globalization? And of course share semantic word plays you've stumbled upon in your (not necessarily native) language.

text:
Guarantee in the future he will move Japanese up quite a bit when he realizes that there are a lot of non-weebs and really interesting/cool people who learn it. Obviously there are a lot people who have a weird relationship with it but you shouldn't judge your language journey based on other people. I've met people who have learned and studied it who haven't even watched anime before. In my opinion Japan is a really unique, mixed bag. On the one hand they have some bad stuff, like toxic work culture, xenophobia (they love other countries culture but refuse to allow immigration), pedophilia in certain subsections of the media, but on the other hand they have some really cool things, like great public infrastructure, very polite society, love of nature, mindfulness, appreciation for cleanliness, etc. Some of their positives are very strong and you won't find them in any other country. Keep in mind Japan is a very big, multifaceted place so your mileage may vary.

Also Portuguese is dank as hell, highly recommend learning it!

text: 2:52 For those unaware of the stereotypical conflict between the two former states of the now united Baden-W√ºrttemberg (the latter often casually referred to as Swabia), the term Badisch in the sense of "German spoken by people from Baden" is much of a convenience word, commonly used to contrast with Swabian German that is used in and strongly associated with W√ºrttemberg, and holds no linguistic value. In fact, "Badisch" could mean any or all of the three major dialect groups native to the region: Sounthern Franconian ("Northern Badisch", most notably spoken around the regional center Karlsruhe), Low Alemannic ("Central Badisch", spoken around Freiburg, Baden-Baden and many parts of the French region of Alsace) and High Alemannic (spoken south of Freiburg and in Northern Switzerland), as well as, ironically, the Swabian and Central Alemannic dialects spoken in a few places in Baden, which are linguistically just the same Swabian and Central Alemannic in W√ºrttemberg. The mentioning of Badisch in the context of this video is of course to provoke dispute for the sake of humor. Nevertheless, the Karlsruhe/Sounthern Franconian dialect (group) could easily be one of the most beautiful dialects of German and is definitely worth some time for polyglot enthusiasts to dig into! Also, greetings from W√ºrttemberg!

text: if i were to learn a german dialect (after hochdeutsch ofc, im b2 there) which ones do you recommend?
author: @yummydragon8533

text: none; just stick with standard german¬†@yummydragon8533¬†
author: @PhilNewman17

text: ¬†@yummydragon8533¬† I'd suggest to start with the dialect(s) you get to hear the most, whether you are currently living in a German-speaking country or have friends with related background. It also helps to know some basic facts about (High) German dialects in general, such as the historical border between High and Low German (Benrath/Speyer lines), the High German consonant shifts, the diphthongization and monophthongization, the umlaut and ablaut in relation to word derivation and conjugation (strong vs. weak inflections), etc. Like the fact that simple grammatical features such as verb conjugations in plural could differ even inside a dialect group (Never wondered how Standard German and Old Dutch have -n/-t/-n, whereas Standard Dutch and Old English have a uniform plural, ending in -n and -√æ respectively? Well some German dialects also have a uniform -n ending, while some others have a uniform -t!). Concerning learning resources, I would recommend learning Luxembourgish, being a full-blown national language and at the same time so closely tied to the neighboring German dialects and comparably close to Standard German feature-wise (in contrast to Swiss German, whose sounds are much exotic to the untrained ears from most parts of Germany and Austria and whose syntax presented challenges even to early computer programs in the past, for that its nested relative clauses terminate in a first-in-first-out order, unlike that of Standard German, where they are like brackets ‚Äì it is as if the Swiss are breaking the bracket rule of mathematics ‚Äì granted, Standard German also have "h√§tte machen m√ºssen" in a subordinate clause, so the complexity is present there, too). I'm not mentioning vocabulary here for the obvious reason that basically every dialect or sociolect variant could have its own special words, and most of them don't hinder you from getting hold of the grammar and phrasal structures typical of the language variant in question. It's also worth some effort to learn some Berlin or Colognian dialect just to be able to make a few humorous remarks as they form a part of the popular culture of the past century.

text: I've been learning Japanese daily for over a year, I don't even really watch anime. Maybe a few per year for immersion if the plot isn't insufferable. I study Japanese is because I genuinely enjoy the writing system, how it sounds, and that it's entirely contextual and as a result it's more straightforward than one would initially expect. Appreciate the language for what it is, that's the primary thing to focus on to learn any language. Culture is mostly a bunch of bullshit that's not worth paying attention to in any tongue, so why would you constrain your enjoyment of something because of what other people do? You choose how you associate with what you do, and if you deliberately gatekeep your experience based on the actions of others, well.. that's beta as fuck.

text: I'm learning Japanese right now, and it's pretty fun. I know you put it in the "dogwater" category because of the weebs, and I don't blame you. That said, if you would like a really non-weeby thing to do in Japan, I suggest the Shikoku Henro Trail. You walk around a whole island, visit 88 temples, and see a side of the country that few western betas get to see. Weebs are scared of the trail because there's no anime shows about it, it's not accessible by the speedy weeb train, and stuff like hiking and physical effort scare them. That and the locals are really friendly and they definitely don't speak American at all, so you'll have to learn it in case you want to get a room to stay in for the night.

My mother language is Serbo-Slovakian which is spoken by about 50.000 people if it counts, it's not really a official language and there are changes with Serbo-Slovakian village to village, though it sounds nothing like Serbian or Slovakian it's a mix influenced by other languages too.

author: @OVER-ce9fy

text: ¬†@Dread_2137¬†  The confusion lies in how different terms are treated in different languages.  In Russian, the word "nationality" means ethnicity and not necessarily as belonging to a specific nation state. That is why many ethnic Russian speaking Russians who may have been born and raised in other countries, will still consider themselves Russian even though they might have never even been to Russia.  This however would be a reference to their ethnicity rather than Russia's residency.  Likewise, many non-Russian ethnic groups inside Russia will consider their nationality to be equal to their ethnic group i.e. Tatar will most likely tell you that their nationality is Tatar or a Chechen will say that her nationality is Chechen, etc.  When we in the west speak of Russians we oftentimes refer to anyone who's from Russia, despite their ethnicity.  However, in Russian language there are two separate and yet similarly sounding words - Russkie (Russians ethnically) and Rossiyane (All-inclusive term for all people who are from Russia despite their ethnic make up).  So the literal definition of the word nationality you're referring to is true for the English speaking world.  I just wanted to give you some context to relate to when you see Russians communicating in English with each other in the comment section and they happen to use the word "nationality".  In most cases, Russians with use this word interchangeably with the word ethnicity because in Russian language the word "nationality" means "ethnicity".
author: @BuckeyeRutabaga

text:
¬†@BuckeyeRutabaga¬† yeah, that's I think is purely russian thing, even in country that's neighboring russia, we don't differentiate between ethnic and non ethnic russians, you're from russia, so you're russian. In old times, when we still were multi-ethnic (so basically before 1939), we used to use latin "gente" and "natione", for example "gente Polonus natione Lithuanus" meaning "Polish by origin, Lithuanian by nationality", or any other combination. So we never differentiated ethnicity and nationality the way russians do. For us, when you call yourself "russian" it means your country of origin, i.e. nationality, if you want to specify ethnicity, you need to say "of origin", for example for a Kazakh born in russia it would be "russian of Kazakh origin", the exception are ethnicities that do not have their own country, such as Crimean Tatars, Chechens, Ainu, Kashubians, etc..
Here "rosjanie" (pronounced the same way as rossiyane) has basically the same meaning as in russian, tho "ruskie" (pronounced the same way as russkie) is more of derogatory way of calling russians, no matter their ethnicity. Which, now that I think about it, is most likely a way of mocking how russians called themselves, in a way they didn't notice we're mocking them, as before 19th century, and before russian, German and Austrian occupation of our territories and people it was a term used only to call (in a non-derogatory way) Ruthenians (today's Ukrainians and Belarusians), so we have historic "ruskie" and modern "ruskie". Sometimes we also used "ruskie" to mean that something is bad or of poor quality, as russian products under communism were rather known for their low quality.

text:
Filipino here. 

Probably a reason as to why people here switch Filipino and English so much (yes, even if someone talks in full English here, there is a chance that a slip of Filipino language will be said during a conversation or even in writing) is because its much more easier to think about that certain word that to scavage the entire Filipino dictionary or in Google just to find the exact word. Sometimes it even isnt the word that I need in that particular sentence because there are words that mean the same-ish thing but its in drastically different ways. And its really not practical for us, especially where we have a lot of foreigner influences  and history that make us just want to use other languages like English wayyyy more.

text:
I'm learning 4 languages (and know 3 others fluently), here's my experience with them:

Spanish: it's easy because I know French already, but it gets boring so quickly because of that. Never knew a language could be this boring tbh. But it is rewarding

Dutch: it's difficult and easy at the same time. The grammar is so damn hard but the words sometimes are easy to learn because of how similar it is to English. Even if I understand each word in a sentence it takes me a while to understand it! Why do Dutch people throw in so many tiny useless words in each sentence?? 

Mandarin: it's very fun to learn! I remember vocabulary very easily and how to read each character (writing is another story). The tones are manageable. Even tho I know like 1k characters I still cannot understand news articles so it's kinda discouraging

Japanese: also very fun to learn, but remembering vocabulary is so hard for me because every word sounds so similar lol. The 3 "alphabets" are manageable, the grammar is okay though annoying at times, but understanding stuff in Japanese feels very rewarding.

text:
If you hate British so much, why haven't you put Welsh on there? The British tried to eradicate Welsh, but was like "fuck you I'm staying" and the Luodingo owl just mothballed it on its app, maybe Luodingo is funded by the British government. 
Wanna stick it to the British? Learn Welsh. 
Love those phlegmy sounds Mongolian makes but don't wanna deal with the extra stuff? Learn Welsh. 
Think dragons are cool and want to learn a badass dragon language? Learn Welsh. 
Want to speak Elden Ring? Learn Welsh. 


And hey, 2 of my target languages made the list. Vietnamese is a great language I agree, though difficult to learn, and I definitely recommend getting used to listening to it. But they were nice enough to give a pretty straight forward & simple grammar system. I was in Vietnam last month but I didn't quite make people do flips.

And Mongolian, now that I've been to Vietnam I get to put a lot more focus on my Mongolian and it a great and pretty unique language. Honestly, it's a nice respite to not have to deal with tones and it's nice not having to listen out for subtle differences in sounds. And the Mongolian script is still used, it's used in Inner Mongolia and Mongolia's government has been rolling it out as an official script, but there are also technical & logistical problems for it to be a primary script.

author: @charleswhitefullbusteruchi1972

text: ¬†@charleswhitefullbusteruchi1972¬† Well, if talking seriously, there were different regional dialects in different parts of the Korean language distribution, that had some distinctions like different sounds/words, and were not defined by the current borders. After the division, the dialects of each country continued independent evolution. In the South Korean dialect a lot of American (and other) loanwords appeared since the import of foreign cultural sings. In the North Korean dialects all the cultural imports are banned and punished by death. Also, there were different spelling reforms conducted in the north and in the south

text:
9:38 As a Turkish, everything he said was correct. Especially the throwing kababs at ppl part.

Jokes aside, we dont do that (unfortunately) but one thing that is common in Turkish ppl is that we absolutely love when foreigners learn our language and try their best to speak it with a broken accent. Until I heard about French ppl, I thought this was common for every language and its native speakers. It is just so common here. We will try our best to help you regardless of whether do you know Turkish or not but knowing Turkish will definetely help you here cus not everyone can speak English fluently here. As I said, we are grateful when we see foreigners speak our language and we also find it a little bit adorable and hilarious when the broken accent is added. I had an American English teacher who learnt Turkish and became a translator before being a teacher. Every time she spoke Turkish, entire class literally celebrated it (Also the rules was strict about English teachers not being allowed to speak Turkish).

author: @birddispenser

text:
¬†@jazdoesnot3dit¬† Cool! I am a super beginner at Russian so I have more of a 90:10 ratio. I prioritize Japanese since I studied it first, but also because I feel like I am cheating on it by studying any Russian at all haha.
I was curious about which one you study more, or do you kind of go 50:50?
author: @birddispenser

text:
¬†@OmerAsh¬† It is not too bad, I stopped putting in as much time into Japanese anyway (dang intermediate plateau) and started telling myself that I made no progress. After being reminded what a true beginner is by starting Russian a week ago I  no longer beat myself up about my Japanese haha. It actually motivated me to study more Japanese too.

On the time problem, I am prioritizing Japanese, so it is probably a 90:10 ratio in favor of Japanese. I just do some Anki and some Drops for Russian to get some vocabulary (limiting myself to 5 new words per day.)
author: @birddispenser

text: ¬†@aizuni¬† That actually makes sense. I've been learning French for a year now. Do you think it's a good idea if I started learning another language alongside French when I'm still a beginner/elementary at French or should I wait until I become good at French first?
author: @OmerAsh

text:
¬†@birddispenser¬† Never heard of intermediate plateau before but I can definitely see myself in that phase at some point in my French learning journey.

Since you're prioritizing Japanese, I'm assuming that it's still difficult to learn 2 languages simultaneously. Otherwise, the ratio would've been 50:50.
author: @OmerAsh

text: ¬†@OmerAsh¬† Probably, but I imagine that some people would be able to do 50:50. I just don't want to because that would mean that I would have to cut down on Japanese or I would have to allocate way more time into language learning. I don't want to do either since I wasn't planning on learning Russian until late 2024-2025 anyway, and it would just eat up time that I want to spend on other hobbies.
author: @birddispenser

English is a Germanic language too but it goes without saying that it‚Äôs very different from other languages in its linguistic family. author: @giopreda

text:

Honestly, I would recommend learning Spanish, French and Romanian to round up all Romance languages, and I say Spanish instead of Portuguese because Spanish is almost 100% mutually intelligible with Portuguese and it shares more linguistic aspects with other Iberian languages than Portuguese does, plus we have more speakers so it‚Äôs easier to communicate with more people if you speak Spanish (you would be able to communicate with Spanish speakers as a Portuguese speaker but obviously their first language is better), as you would potentially be learning the language not only to understand other Romance language speakers but to speak to the natives too!

text: That‚Äôs because it is obviously not a Romance / Latin language, just misclassified, same as Farsi etc! Around 4:23 is also very incorrect, it‚Äôs not a Latin language at all, not even true Slavic, and it is one of the most non-pretty and uncouth looking / sounding languages ever with embarrassingly funny sounding words and word endings, totally not an Alpha language, it‚Äôs as non-pretty as Indian languages and Japanese and African languages lol, and, the most accurate classification would be Thracian-Aslavic or something similar, technically those groups of languages were made by greek dudes and dudes that moved away from Greece, so it has a lot more similarities with Greek and languages such as Bulgarian and Serbian and Albanian! Having many words modified from a Latin word does not make a language Latin and having many words modified from Proto European does not make a language European, and Indian languages aren‚Äôt European either since they aren‚Äôt similar to European languages in any way, as all these languages have been modified into completely different languages, and it‚Äôs the word endings and the letter combinations and the sound or sound patterns that make a language what it is, tho there are multiple less known languages that have been classified incorrectly, including languages that have not been classified in a complete and accurate way ‚Äî technically all languages that exist today come from Proto European, either directly or indirectly, anyway, so it doesn‚Äôt really mean anything, and the classifications should reflect each language and what it has been modified into, not using ancient languages that its Old and Middle versions may have been modified from in its classification despite the fact that the new language that was made doesn‚Äôt look or sound at all like Proto European or European languages or Latin etc, so the classifications should always be accurate and complete, which would make everything way less confusing!
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text: None of the actual Romance languages are similar to it, Latin languages have the typical Latin word endings and letter combinations which give them that refined and elegant and pretty sound and aspect, the exact opposite of its word endings and letter combinations, it is a Thracian-Aslavic language modified from Greek and Albanian and some Slavic languages, there is a version of it that is a half-Slavic language as it looks and sounds Slavic, or almost Slavic, but even the actual Slavic languages don‚Äôt look and don‚Äôt sound uncouth as that group of languages, and having some words from Latin doesn‚Äôt make a language Latin, like, English has way more words from Latin languages than any other language, yet it is 100% Germanic, as it sounds and looks Germanic, so vocab doesn‚Äôt mean anything, that‚Äôs not how languages work, it‚Äôs all about the word endings and letter combinations etc and the sound patterns which are influenced by the letter combinations and word endings, so, it‚Äôs not Latin and it‚Äôs not truly Slavic either, it was misclassified, should have been classified differently, in its own group with the other versions, since it isn‚Äôt real similar to any other types of languages, more like Thracian-Aslavic, tho it does have a Slavic intonation overall, but the sound patterns are not really similar to those of Slavic languages, only the intonation!
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text: I highly recommend learning Icelandic / Norse / Dutch / English / Norwegian 2gether at the same time, which are the prettiest and most refined / magical / poetic languages ever created and the most alpha languages etc, as they are way too pretty not to know, they are a must-know for every learner, so I highly recommend learning these 5 first, and learning all the lyrics from Sk√°ld songs which are also awesome, and Galician / Portuguese / Gallo are the prettiest Latin languages, and when it comes to Latin languages, one should start with Galician because it is also the easiest Latin language ever with the lightest spelling and it is based on Spanish + Portuguese, and I also highly recommend learning Welsh / Breton / Cornish (the other 3 modern Celtic languages Manx / Irish / Scottish Gaelic are also gorgeous) and Hungarian (way better option than Turkish) and Slovene (the prettiest and easiest Slavic language) and Danish / Faroese / Gothic etc, and all other Germanic languages are great options as well, but one should definitely start with the first five which truly are the prettiest ever and also the most fun to learn / speak / see etc ‚Äî technically, one can learn many of them at the same time, as they are easy category 1 and category 2 languages (only Irish and Scottish Gaelic are both category 3 languages) and learning many languages at the same time saves a lot of years and is way more fun, and, I am learning about 15+ of these languages myself, having started learning languages on my own one year ago, and I am already advanced level in Norwegian and upper advanced level in Dutch and upper intermediate in Icelandic / Norse / German and intermediate in like 5 other languages, so it‚Äôs definitely the most efficient way to learn as many pretty languages as possible in only a few years!
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text:
By the way, my current levels are... 
- upper intermediate level in Old Norse / Icelandic / German  
- writer level in English + native speaker level in Spanish 
- upper advanced level in Dutch + advanced level in Norwegian 
- intermediate level in Swedish / Portuguese / French / Italian / Welsh 
- beginner level in Breton / Hungarian / Gothic / Latin / Faroese / Galician / Danish / Slovene  
- total beginner in Cornish / Manx / Irish / Scottish Gaelic / Aranese / Elfdalian / Gallo / Limburgish / Occitan / Luxembourgish / Catalan / Urkers / Hunsrik / East Norse / Ruhrp√∂ttisch / Alemannic / Ripuarian / Swiss German / P√§lzische Deutsch / Austrian German / Waddisch / Palatine German / Westf√∂√§lsk Sassisk / Austro-Bavarian / PlatDeitsch / Greenlandic Norse / Friulian / Pretarolo / Sardinian / Neapolitan / Sicilian / Venetian / Esperanto / Walloon / Ladin / Guernsey / Norn / Burgundian / Sognam√•l / West Frisian / North Frisian / East Frisian / Yiddish / Afrikaans / Finnish / Latvian / Estonian etc (and the other languages based on Dutch / German / Norwegian / Italian / French that are referred to as ‚Äòdialects‚Äô but are usually a different language with different spelling etc) 
(I highly recommend learning English 2gether with Dutch / Icelandic + Norse + Faroese / Norwegian as they are so magical, as pretty / refined / poetic as English ‚Äî all other Germanic and the other pretty languages on my list are also gorgeous, so they are all a great option!)
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text: Besides, why would one want to learn a non-pretty language that doesn‚Äôt sound good and refined and isn‚Äôt even Latin (I still cannot understand how did it get misclassified as Latin when it is clearly not Latin at all, completely different word endings and letter combinations that aren‚Äôt used in any Latin languages and odd letters that aren‚Äôt used in Latin languages either) that has embarrassingly funny sounding words just as Japanese and Indian languages and African languages and Korean etc, one should think twice before recommending non-pretty languages, and one should always look at the words in their written form before deciding to learn or recommend anything, and all should choose wisely, only the pretty and easy languages (which can be found on my list of pretty languages that I want to learn and improve) for their pretty words, as pretty languages aka languages with mostly or almost only pretty words and great or good pronunciation rules are naturally fun and motivating and they are the languages that truly dsv the attention ‚Äî also, the true Latin languages are on my list, and Galician / Portuguese / Gallo / Catalan / Latin are the prettiest Latin languages, and Occitan is also real pretty, so I highly recommend learning one of these first, and maybe also starting to learn either Italian and Spanish, but Portuguese or Galician would be a great option for any new learner, when it comes to Latin languages, but first one should learn the five prettiest languages ever Icelandic / Norse / English / Dutch / Norwegian which are real works of art, and if one decides to learn many languages at the same time, like I do, one should also include either Portuguese or Galician, and Breton and / or Welsh, and maybe even Hungarian and Slovene!
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text:
¬†@thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038¬† Hi! Language family classifications aren‚Äôt based on sound or word endings, they‚Äôre mostly based on history, grammatical structure and vocabulary, but mostly just history. Romance languages don‚Äôt all have a specific sound, just look at Spanish and French, they sound completely different! Heck, even different accents between the same language sound different, and there are languages that sound like another one yet aren‚Äôt even related. Guarani, an indigenous language from South America, sounds a lot like some South Eastern Asian languages yet has nothing to do with it, and Mexican, Colombian, Spaniard and Argentinian Spanish sound really different from each other but are all the same language. Regarding Romanian, we can trace back its development from Latin and we can see the Slavic influence in its vocabulary, but because it developed on a straight line from Latin throughout the centuries we can classify it as a Romance language. It‚Äôs on its own category though, Eastern Romance, which apart from Romanian includes lesser languages and extinct languages, most of them similarly influenced by Slavic or Uralic languages.

English is a Germanic language but has French influences not only in it‚Äôs vocabulary but also its grammar and to a lesser extent its phonetics system, although it really doesn‚Äôt share a lot with other Germanic languages either on that regard.
author: @giopreda

text: ¬†@thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038¬† Trying to learn Dutch, do you have any general strategies with what to start if it's not too much to ask? Or any resources that were useful to you?
author: @brandonmunson9781

text:
By the way, I learned Spanish to a native speaker level in childhood in a 100% passive way, and I am so glad I did, because I don‚Äôt think I would want to actively learn Spanish on my own, so, I can easily learn the others like Italian and French and Portuguese and Catalan and Latin and Gallo and Sardinian and Galician and Occitan etc without having to translate most words one by one because most words are obvious cognates and usually have the same meaning! 

Knowing Spanish and English definitely gives one a huge advantage, because most vocab videos only have English translations and because it‚Äôs easier to learn other Latin languages if one knows at least one Latin language and English, especially considering the fact that many of the words in Latin languages aren‚Äôt as easy to memorize as almost all Germanic words (Germanic words are the easiest to memorize and have the most organized aspect, which makes Germanic languages the easiest languages ever) especially if one doesn‚Äôt know any Latin language yet, but if one knows at least one Latin language, even memorizing other Latin words gets easier, and, even though actively learning languages such as Spanish and French and Italian (and even German) isn‚Äôt that fun, knowing at least one of them will definitely make the process easier! 

But the language that are the most fun to learn are the prettiest languages ever, because the prettier a language is, the more fun it is to learn, so learning French and Italian and German and Swedish and Finnish etc is definitely nowhere near as fun as learning Icelandic and Norse and Dutch and Norwegian and Faroese and Gothic and Danish and Breton and Welsh etc, for example, but I am still learning them, because I want to know all the pretty languages, even the ones that are less pretty, but I just don‚Äôt prioritize them as much as I prioritize the prettiest languages! 

The top three most fun foreign languages to learn are Norse and Icelandic and Dutch, definitely the most fun ever, I get so joyful when I see the words and when I hear the gorgeous sounds and pronunciation rules, and I don‚Äôt get that feeling with most other languages, as these three are very special and simply heavenly, just like English! 

I already know English, but for a non-native speaker of English learning new words in English to get to a native speaker level would probably be as fun as learning those three, as they are equally gorgeous!
author: @thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038

text:
¬†@thetrueoneandonlyladyprinc8038¬†   Are you seriously recommending languages based on ‚Äúprettiness‚Äù? I mean, first of all, what‚Äôs pretty or not varies from person to person, I speak Dutch fluently but I find it one of the ‚Äúugliest‚Äù languages I speak if one can even say that about languages.
Second of all, I mean, the main purpose of language learning is to communicate with people, so why should Old Norse be the first language anyone learns when there are virtually none native speakers? I mean, you do you, and it‚Äôs great you like learning new languages, but none of your advice is universal. Personally I find that learning many languages at the same time actually makes my learning process slower in all of them and gets them mixed up in my brain. I personally also couldn‚Äôt care less about how ‚Äúpretty‚Äù a language is and I learn them purely for utilitarian purposes, so learning Old Norse is not on my to-do list any time soon.

text:
I am not sure if it was a joke, but Ukrainian is overall closer to Russian than to Polish by many parameters. Although Polish is itself closer to Russian than it may seem and Ukrainian has a lot of unique features not found in both of the languages, but the pronunciation, the morphology, the grammar and the basic lexicon still put Ukrainian closer to Russian.
PS: Ukrainian does have the "—ã" sound, but it's written with character "–∏".

text: ‚Äã¬†@–ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä–ú–∏–ª–æ—Ä–∞–¥–æ–≤–∏—á¬†which is simply because, like in all former Soviet republics, Russian was the main language in Ukraine for a long time, and Ukrainization started only after 2014, so for the majority of adult Ukrainians Russian is still familiar. But for their kids/grandchildren who, unlike their ancestors, no longer have to learn Russian since the young age, it will be as hard to understand Russian as it is for Russians to understand Ukrainian
author: @jasont4206

text: @lotus18_sSI struggle with originally Ukrainian words. You know, like the name of months in Ukrainian, it‚Äôs really a torture. I think most of Ukrainians understand Russian because they were taught it with Ukrainian, but I‚Äôve noticed, that children whose parents used only Ukrainian don‚Äôt understand Russian. When I was in Ukraine in the part, where people mostly use ukranian my 6 years old cousin struggled with understanding my speech cause i can speak only Russian and he didn‚Äôt understand me
author: @dasharemenyak

text: ‚Äã¬†@jasont4206¬†There are many regions in Ukraine where Russian speech has never been heard, and believe me, when they grow up and come to other regions of the country where Russian is spoken, they understand it.  Moreover, this is something new for them, and they consider the Russian language to be a dialect... or an adverb.  The Soviet Union influenced Ukrainian society, but it was unable to influence remote regions, which for the most part did not care about the USSR.
author: @ilyadmitrenko4065

text: ¬†@ilyadmitrenko4065¬† of course they can understand some 60-70% of words without prior exposure to the language - many Russians can understand 60-70% of Ukrainian and Belarusian without prior exposure too - since they all are Slavic languages and there's been active exchange between them due to geographical proximity and historical conditions that I mentioned earlier.

text:
You can use cases to show dependencies between parts of a sentence. So you can determine exactly whether something is a subject or an object and how they relate to each other.

For example:

I, you, he/she/it is the nominative case

My, Mine, your(s), his/her(s)/its is the possesive case or the genetive

I think cases are pretty cool üòÖ

¬†@angie.666¬† Being a native Italian speaker and having studied Latin, I can't help but notice some similarities with Russian. Like, —ç—Ç–æ –±—ã–ª–æ, –æ–Ω–∞ –±—ã–ª–∞ and –º—ã –±—ã–ª–∏, the endings of the verbs consist of similar letters to the ones I would have used in Italian (√® stato, √® stata, siamo stati). Also, possession is expressed just like it once was in Latin: 'to me is something'.
Languages are so fascinating, they carry the heritage of the people who moved across the continents for thousands of years. Who knows where these similarities come from.

Also, Russian is just plain out cool.

I'll do Spanish then Romanian then Serbian.
