text:
Um, it shouldn‚Äôt, because most of them are not correct rankings, the prettiest and the most refined and the most amazing languages ever are Icelandic / Norse / Dutch / English / Norwegian (too pretty not to know, so all learners should learn and know these five, which are way too pretty not to know and the languages of the future) and also Faroese / Danish / Gothic etc (all Germanic languages are amazing) and also the modern Celtic languages Welsh / Breton / Cornish / Manx / Irish / Scottish Gaelic (almost as amazing as the prettiest Germanic languages, very similar to Norse and Dutch and English in sound patterns and letter combinations and word endings) and Hungarian and Slovene (the prettiest Slavic language) etc, while Russian / Arabic / Polish / Bulgarian / Czech etc are just kinda avrg with mostly neutral words and only a few pretty words, and most other languages are not pretty at all! 

For example, around 4:23 it is very incorrect, not even a Latin language, and it‚Äôs one of the most non-pretty languages ever, same as Japanese and Indian languages and African languages and Korean etc, yet it got an ‚ÄòAlpha‚Äô ranking just because of the natives‚Äô reactions, while the truly Alpha languages didn‚Äôt get the Alpha rankings that they dsv!¬†

Perfect and amazing languages such as the Germanic languages and the modern Celtic languages and the actual Latin languages and Slovene and Hungarian (these ones are the real pretty languages) and also Finnish / Latvian / Estonian, which also have mostly pretty words and nice word endings, should definitely have their own list, in a way, as most of the rest of the languages that exist cannot even come close! 

Dutch is literally one of the prettiest languages ever, its words and sounds and diphthongs are simply gorgeous, way prettier than in German, and there are many versions of soft Gs and soft Rs etc, and Norwegian is way prettier than Swedish and it has a prettier spelling than Danish, so they should be ranked as the Alpha languages, and the other true Alpha languages are Icelandic and Norse (the most Alpha languages ever) and English and Faroese and Gothic! 

So I highly recommend choosing wisely, only the pretty and easy languages for their pretty words and sounds, and learning as many of the pretty languages as one can handle, just like I do!

√ûa√∞ er mikilv√¶gt a√∞ l√¶ra √çslensku og FornNorrenu og Hollensku og Norsku, √æv√≠ √æ√¶r eru alltof flottar og fullkomnar! üá≥üá± üáÆüá∏ üá´üá¥ üá≥üá¥ üá∫üá∏ üá∏üá™ üá±üá∫ üá©üá∞ üá©üá™ üáÆüá™ üá¨üáß üá≠üá∫ üá¶üá∫ I shall share examples of sentences in Norse and Icelandic and Dutch and some of the prettiest Norwegian words... 
Ek veit √æat, en √æu veist √æat ekki... (√æ = the TH sound in think) 
√âg veit √æa√∞ √æ√∫ veist ekki... (√∞ = the TH sound in the English word that and It is pronounced like the TH in the English word think when it is at the end of the word and and √©g is pronounced yeh and ekki is pronounced ehki in Modern Icelandic) 
Ek heitumk Freyja ok ek em at l√¶ra FornNorrenu ok √çslensku... (the √¶ in l√¶ra is pronounced like an open A sound like in the English word cat and the u is pronounced more like an yu / iu sound with an extra i sound like the u in French and like the √º in German) 
√ûa√∞ er ekki at ver√∞a a√∞ger√∞arlaust e√∞a √≥√∫treiknanlegt... (au = eoi sound in Modern Icelandic which is normal e sound + normal o sound + normal i sound said fast in one sound and the g and k in √≥√∫treiknanlegt are pronounced like a soft h sound) 
Ik hou van Nederlands ‚Äî et is zo‚Äôn unieke en geweldige taal... 
So one can see how pretty and how alpha these languages look and sound ‚Äî and the pronunciation rules are so modern and so cool, definitely the prettiest and coolest sounds and pronunciation rules ever, these languages sound as cool as English, and maybe a bit cooler even, in some ways!

text: It is a fact that they are the prettiest, anyone with functional eye / ear can see and hear that ‚Äî almost every word in the five prettiest languages Norse / Icelandic / English / Dutch / Norwegian and in the other Germanic languages and in the 6 modern Celtic languages is super gorgeous and a real work of art that very few languages creators were / are capable of, just as very few singers have a naturally pretty voice that is higher and lighter (such as the singer that sang the Sk√°ld songs S√¶konungar and R√∫n and the singer that sang the Nightwish songs Storytime and Amaranth or the singer that sang the song Riding On The Rocks from the movie Ring Of The Nibelungs etc) and just as very few can make a pretty melody (such as the songs by Sk√°ld and Nightwish and Varien etc) because, very few have or had natural artistic talent, which is required to be able to create well-constructed and pretty languages (that are created by following the most logical patterns and by combining sounds and letters that go well 2gether, as opposed to just making random words with random syllables and random sounds and random letters sl√¶pt 2gether) and pretty melodies and well-written and pretty lyrics etc!
author: @FrozenMermaid666

text:
Germanic languages are the prettiest languages ever created, and then the 6 modern Celtic languages which are almost as gorgeous as the prettiest Germanic languages, and then Hungarian, and then Galician / Latin / Gallo etc, and Slovene, and languages such as Finnish / Latvian / Estonian ‚Äî these are the pretty languages that exist! 

Languages such as Russian and Polish and Filipino and Indonesian and Albanian and Greek etc are just avrg, not pretty, as they have a lot of pretty words, but they have mostly neutral words and lots of non-pretty words! 

Swedish is a pretty language since it‚Äôs Germanic, but not as pretty as Norwegian ‚Äî Norwegian Bokm√•l is the prettiest of the three, and then Danish, which comes from Norwegian Bokm√•l, but its spelling isn‚Äôt as pretty as the spelling of Norwegian, and then Swedish!¬†

Esperanto is a pretty language, but its grammar needs some improving! 

Spanish is a pretty language as well, as it is a Latin language with Latin word endings and letter combinations that also has a lot of influence from English! 

Chinese languages and other similar languages are very poorly-constructed and sound very non-pretty like yelling in different pitches or different tones with short one-syllable words that look and sound the same and that are very confusing, though they also have a few pretty words like lin / yin / xie / yang / fizi / hen / wuzi / ni hao etc!
author: @FrozenMermaid666

text:
I have seen and heard thousands of languages and at least one language from every language family, and most languages that exist are just random g that shouldn‚Äôt even have been made, and all speakers should be learning and speaking the pretty languages instead, including the five prettiest languages ever created Norse / Icelandic / English / Dutch / Norwegian which are the languages of the future, as the pretty languages are the ones that truly dsv the attention!¬†

There are probably less than 100 pretty languages, and I have about 50 or 60 of them on my list ‚Äî a pretty language is a language that has mostly or almost only pretty words aka well-constructed words that have good or great letter combinations and pretty word endings as well as pretty sounds and pretty pronunciation rules etc, and that have that perfect flow and harmony, and that also have the perfect balance between short words and medium words and long words as well as a very organized aspect, and that use a proper alphabet, such as the Latin alphabet aka the best and the most logical and the easiest alphabet ever!¬†

I also know the Runic alphabet and the Gothic alphabet (the 2nd easiest alphabets, after the Latin alphabet which is the easiest ever) which are also proper alphabets with pretty letters that are based on the Latin alphabet (or maybe the Latin alphabet is based on Runes) and the Cyrillic alphabet (the 3rd easiest alphabet) and, trying to learn the Greek alphabet as well, and I also want to learn the Devanagari alphabet because it looks very interesting, so that I can write words from the languages I know using any of these alphabets!

text:
As a norwegian speaker, i believe it should at least be alpha
Personally, on its own, i think its already pretty good language, but thats personal opinion, and that doesnt matter
My main defence is that bokm√•l norwegian (the main version of norwegian people learn)
Is very similar to danish written
So if you can read/write bokm√•l, then you can communicate with danish people (without sticking a potato in your mouth)
And spoken norwegian is close enough to spoken swedish, that you can easily commicate with swedish people, without even learning swedish
(Also it is close enough that you can understand written swedish, but not as well as understanding spoken swedish=

So basically, norwegian is a bridge language that allows you to communicate with both swedish and danish people
Meaning, it should at least be at the midpoint between swedish and danish, aka alpha
But in reality, it should be a Gigachad language

text:
For example, the harsh Hs in Arabic are way harsher than the hard Gs used in Dutch, and unlike Dutch, which has all sorts of Gs from the softest to the hardest G, Arabic has no soft H versions, and Arabic isn‚Äôt a pretty language as it only has a few pretty words, maybe ten to twenty percent of the words, while most words are just neutral, so it‚Äôs an avrg language, same as Polish and Russian and Bulgarian etc!¬†

Slovene is definitely the prettiest and most refined Slavic language, Hungarian is a pretty language that‚Äôs a way better option than Turkish (as it has the good sounds and the good letter combinations and the good pretty word endings found in Turkish, minus the non-pretty ones, plus Hungarian has a way lighter spelling and a very organized aspect, having been influenced a lot by Germanic languages, so if one is thinking about learning Turkish, one should definitely learn Hungarian instead of Turkish) and, the prettiest Latin languages are Galician / Brazilian Portuguese / Gallo and Occitan and Latin are also real pretty and are even prettier than Spanish and Italian and French etc! 

Around 4:23 is is also very incorrect, it‚Äôs not a Latin language at all, not even true Slavic, and it is one of the most non-pretty and uncouth looking / sounding languages ever with embarrassingly funny sounding words and word endings, totally not an Alpha language, it‚Äôs as non-pretty as Indian languages and Japanese and African languages lol, and, the most accurate classification would be Thracian-Aslavic or something similar, technically those groups of languages were made by greek dudes and dudes that moved away from Greece, so it has a lot more similarities with Greek and languages such as Bulgarian and Serbian and Albanian!¬†

Perfect and amazing languages such as the Germanic languages and the modern Celtic languages and also the other pretty languages such as the actual Latin languages and Slovene and Hungarian (these ones are the real pretty languages) and, Finnish / Latvian / Estonian, which also have mostly pretty words and nice word endings are all great options, so all learners should learn any of them / some of them / all of them etc, including the prettiest ever which are Icelandic / Norse / Dutch / English / Norwegian! 

I am learning all the pretty languages, and am learning 15+ languages at the moment and mostly prioritizing Icelandic and Norse and Welsh over the past few weeks, and am advanced level in Norwegian and upper advanced level in Dutch, so I can understand almost every sentence and word at this point, and I am extremely close to an advanced level in Icelandic as well as I‚Äôve been learning hundreds of new words every day or almost every day lately and I can already follow sentences and have recently started watching everything with Icelandic subs!

text: Dutch is literally one of the prettiest languages ever created with perfect words and sounds, and most speakers of Dutch use soft Gs and medium Gs, only in Amsterdam the harder Gs are used a lot, and Swedish is totally not prettier than Norwegian, Swedish is one of the least prettier Nordic languages, though it is still pretty, while Norwegian Bokm√•l has the best spelling / aspect, definitely better looking than both Swedish and Danish spelling, and, Icelandic is definitely the most feminine (but also the most masculine) language ever, just like Norse and English and Dutch, these four languages all sound the most feminine when spoken by speakers with higher voices that are naturally pretty and light, and they also sound the most alpha and the most masculine when spoken by speakers with deeper voices, having the coolest and the most modern pronunciation rules, and Danish also, and the pronunciation rules are definitely better in Danish than in Norwegian and Swedish, but they are easier in Norwegian, so Norwegian and Icelandic and Norse are great options to start with, and I highly recommend learning all, I am already advanced level in Norwegian and very close to advanced level in Icelandic (upper intermediate level, and also in Norse and German) and upper advanced level in Dutch, which is definitely the easiest language or one of the easiest languages to learn for English speakers, and I highly recommend using the soft G and the soft normal R + the Americanized R aka de gooise R which have the best and most refined sound! Also, the harsh Hs in Arabic are way harsher than the hard Gs used in Dutch, and unlike Dutch, which has all sorts of Gs from the softest to the hardest G, Arabic has no soft H versions, and Arabic isn‚Äôt a pretty language as it only has a few pretty words, maybe ten to twenty percent of the words, while most words are just neutral, so it‚Äôs an avrg language, same as Polish and Russian and Bulgarian etc! text: The prettiest Dutch accent is the accent that uses the Americanized R and softer Rs at the beginning of the words and the softer Gs, so I highly recommend learning this accent, instead of the typical Amsterdam accent, and I highly recommend learning or training oneself to speak slower and to properly enunciate each syllables, as speaking very clearly and using soft Rs and soft Gs definitely brings out the best sounds of the Dutch language ‚Äî the main reasons why spoken Dutch doesn‚Äôt sound good sometimes are, the speaker‚Äôs voice (many ppl in general have very non-pretty voices or timbres, and unfortunately one cannot do anything about that) and not enunciating the syllables properly (this can make pretty languages sound odd and not so good) and speaking way too fast and / or in a mumbled way (this can make any pretty language not sound good) and using a very hard R (Rs are one of those problematic sounds, just like the CH and SH and TS sounds, and they can make a pretty language not sound good if they are rolled or thrilled or over-thrilled, so, the softer the Rs etc are pronounced, the better it will sound) and using a harder G or a very hard guttural G (the harder Gs don‚Äôt sound good, and when they are extremely hard, they can be very distracting and can definitely upset the listener‚Äôs ear, though medium soft to medium Gs are pretty tolerable, so I don‚Äôt really mind them, but the soft Gs have the best sound, so all speakers should use soft Gs) and, these can be fixed / changed, except for the first one because one cannot change the timbre of one‚Äôs voice unfortunately, but anyway, the language itself is a real work of art, and almost every Dutch word is so gorgeous, some of the prettiest Dutch words being verdween / adem / ver / blikje / voorheen etc, and, the accents or the pronunciation of certain speakers doesn‚Äôt change the fact that Dutch is one of the prettiest languages ever, so I don‚Äôt understand how could anyone try to deny that!

text:
8:30 üò¢ sad Greek noises 
Honestly though, Greece is a nice place to visit, so in that case, it would be worth it to at least know how to say malakas (you'll definitely get a backflip). Plus, there's so much to read, and the European languages have been massively influenced by Greek in terms of vocabulary. Imagine words like democracy, "rule of the people", from demos meaning people and kratos meaning state/authority. Or the telephone, "remote voice", from tele meaning far, and phone meaning voice. Learning Greek isn't just about speaking it, it unlocks a deeper understanding of all the European languages you already know or might be planning to learn. Also, there's a large Greek speaking area in southern Albania, close to the border with Greece, so that should also be an interesting vacation destination.

text: Dutch is literally one of the prettiest languages ever created with perfect words and sounds, and most speakers of Dutch use soft Gs and medium Gs, only in Amsterdam the harder Gs are used a lot, and Swedish is totally not prettier than Norwegian, Swedish is one of the least prettier Nordic languages, though it is still pretty, while Norwegian Bokm√•l has the best spelling / aspect, definitely better looking than both Swedish and Danish spelling, and, Icelandic is definitely the most feminine (but also the most masculine) language ever, just like Norse and English and Dutch, these four languages all sound the most feminine when spoken by speakers with higher voices that are naturally pretty and light, and they also sound the most alpha and the most masculine when spoken by speakers with deeper voices, having the coolest and the most modern pronunciation rules, and Danish also, and the pronunciation rules are definitely better in Danish than in Norwegian and Swedish, but they are easier in Norwegian, so Norwegian and Icelandic and Norse are great options to start with, and I highly recommend learning all at the same time! I am already advanced level in Norwegian and very close to advanced level in Icelandic (upper intermediate level, and also in Norse and German) and upper advanced level in Dutch, which is definitely the easiest language or one of the easiest languages to learn for English speakers, and I highly recommend using the soft G and the soft normal R + the Americanized R aka de gooise R which have the best and most refined sound, and, I am learning 15+ languages at the moment and mostly prioritizing Icelandic and Norse and Welsh over the past few weeks! Around 4:23 is vey incorrect, not a Latin language, and it‚Äôs one of the most non-pretty languages ever, so it doesn‚Äôt even belong on the same list with perfect and amazing languages such as the Germanic languages and the modern Celtic languages and the Latin languages and Slovene and Hungarian (these ones are the real pretty languages) and also Finnish / Latvian / Estonian, which also have mostly pretty words and nice word endings! Also, the harsh Hs in Arabic are way harsher than the hard Gs used in Dutch, and unlike Dutch, which has all sorts of Gs from the softest to the hardest G, Arabic has no soft H versions, and Arabic isn‚Äôt a pretty language as it only has a few pretty words, maybe ten to twenty percent of the words, while most words are just neutral, so it‚Äôs an avrg language, same as Polish and Russian and Bulgarian etc! Slovene is definitely the prettiest and most refined Slavic language, Hungarian is a pretty language that‚Äôs a way better option than Turkish (as it has the good sounds and the good letter combinations and the good pretty word endings found in Turkish, minus the non-pretty ones, plus Hungarian has a way lighter spelling and a very organized aspect, having been influenced a lot by Germanic languages, so if one is thinking about learning Turkish, one should definitely learn Hungarian instead of Turkish) and, the prettiest Latin languages are Galician / Brazilian Portuguese / Gallo and Occitan and Latin are also real pretty and are even prettier than Spanish and Italian and French etc!
author: @FrozenMermaid666

text:
Around 4:23 is very incorrect, it‚Äôs not a Latin language at all, not even true Slavic, and it is one of the most non-pretty and uncouth looking / sounding languages ever with embarrassingly funny sounding words and word endings, totally not an Alpha language, it‚Äôs as non-pretty as Indian languages and Japanese and African languages lol, and, the most accurate classification would be Thracian-Aslavic or something similar, technically those groups of languages were made by greek dudes and dudes that moved away from Greece, so it has a lot more similarities with Greek and languages such as Bulgarian and Serbian and Albanian ‚Äî while Germanic languages are all amazing languages, with Icelandic / Norse / English / Dutch / Norwegian / Danish being the best ever! 

Re the language Farsi or Persian etc, it is actually an Arabic language, not an European language, as it looks and sounds Arabic! In truth, all languages come from Proto European, in one way or another, anyway, so it isn‚Äôt a complete or really accurate classification, plus European languages are not similar to Indian languages at all, and Indian languages are similar to Arabic languages, as they have influenced each other! Thing is, many of the less known languages have been misclassified as they haven‚Äôt been properly analyzed and compared to the languages spoken in the neighboring countries, so not all the classifications are accurate or complete!¬†

As for Hungarian, it is one of the pretty languages, unlike most languages on this list, and most of the ‚Äòcases‚Äô are actually just the postpositions aka the prepositions of the agglutinative languages, which are added to the noun and written as one word, and Hungarian is a category 2 language, so it‚Äôs very easy to read / learn / memorize etc and it has a category 1 pronunciation, and it has mostly pretty words like Germanic languages and modern Celtic languages!

text:
Wow, ¬†@FrozenMermaid666¬†, what a burst of flow... I love it but it's difficult to follow, need to borrow a full stop? Do you happen to be Dutch, I wonder? I speak Dutch and several other European languages and Dutch is by far the easiest to learn (if you're motivated enough, which is seldom the case). It's basically simplified German with a heavy pronunciation twist and some ingredients of Frisian language, which in turn is closer to English. But easy languages are not a great tool for expression. The ultimate tool for evaluating a language apart from your personal preferences ("the melody") is the literature. The great achievements in writing and poetry define the superiority of a language. So next to funny Simp's rankings, thumbs up to those, the objective ranking would still put Russian, German, French, Spanish, (sorry Italians and English!) in the first tier, and then Polish, Serbian, Bulgarian, Czech, Irish, Armenian and then only Scandinavian languages. Hungary has great culture but the language barrier is too high for me to absorb their superb poetry (in music they are second to none). Practically all the pillars of the Christianity rest on the heritage of Greek language solely, so that cannot be taken out of equation too. The huge problem is that the languages promptly reflect the shifts in cultural and spiritual development, so most of the recent "great" languages from the objective first tier and all those that I speak succumb to decay we are witnessing in this century, and especially that of the last several years. 
P. S. If you are going to learn Portuguese, go definitely instead learn Serbian, it sounds similarly macho and is better organized, has some borrowed German and Turkish words for your convenience plus covers four or five more lands in the region.
